content: UZIO Overview: Platform, Modules, Key Features
What is UZIO?

UZIO is an all-in-one HR, payroll, benefits, and time platform that centralizes people operations—covering payroll and tax, HRIS, benefits/, time & attendance, expenses, compliance, and reporting. UZIO Co-Pilot is in-app AI assistant that answers questions, automates routine actions, and guides admins through complex HR, Payroll, and Benefits workflows to reduce time-to-completion.
Modules of UZIO Platform
Time Tracking & Scheduling

UZIO’s Time Tracking and Scheduling module lets teams capture time exactly where work happens—on the web, in the Employer/Employee portals, the UZIO Mobile App, or a shared Time Kiosk. Employees clock in/out, record meals and rests, and see their hours in one place, while managers get a clean review flow for daily checks and end-of-period approvals. Everything is designed to be quick for frontline users and auditable for admins, so you reduce corrections and speed up payroll.

Break compliance is built in. You can define meal and rest policies (paid or unpaid), set eligibility thresholds and repeat rules, and choose whether to auto-deduct or simply flag missing breaks for attestation. This gives you the flexibility to match local laws and company policy without forcing a one-size-fits-all rule across teams. When exceptions occur, they’re visible and traceable—so you can correct issues before they reach payroll.

Scheduling is just as streamlined. Managers create and publish shifts, make updates, and ensure coverage across locations or roles. Employees see their assigned shifts on web and mobile as soon as schedules are published, helping reduce no-shows and last-minute confusion. Simple controls keep the learning curve low, so planners can move quickly even during high-change periods.

Managers can publish Open Shifts for eligible employees to claim on mobile. Employees can Offer their assigned shift to coworkers or request a Swap; these actions route to managers for approve/decline, and once published, updates hit everyone’s calendars. Eligibility rules (e.g., same work location) are enforced so coverage changes stay compliant and auditable.

Manager workflows tie the whole process together. You can monitor who’s on the clock right now, review timesheets for your direct reports, approve or send back changes, and sync hours to payroll when they’re final. Because time and schedules live in the same system as HR and payroll, data flows forward with fewer exports, fewer manual edits, and a clear audit trail from shift plan → time worked → payroll.
Time off

UZIO’s Time Off module gives employees a clear, self-service experience to request time off, check balances, and track history from the web and the UZIO Mobile App. On web, employees hit Request Time Off, enter dates, reasons, and see their current balances before submitting. On mobile, Time Off lives right in the bottom navigation so people can request from anywhere without emailing HR.

For admins, policies and holidays are centralized and configurable. You can add and manage Time Off policies, then assign them to employees; holiday calendars are created from the same area so observed holidays flow into balances and availability. This keeps policy rules and holidays consistent across teams and locations.

The approvals flow is built in. Employees submit; managers are notified and can approve/deny with notes. Admin dashboards let you review pending requests at a glance, reducing email back-and-forth and keeping decisions auditable. That visibility cuts down on surprises at payroll time and makes it easy to enforce blackout dates or staffing minimums.

Finally, Time Off is wired to payroll and scheduling. Approved PTO and unpaid time off sync to payroll and, for salaried employees, regular hours adjust automatically when unpaid time is used. If your PTO accrues off hours worked, using UZIO for both Payroll and PTO ensures automatic accrual calculations without manual reconciliation. This end-to-end flow moves you from policy → request → approval → pay with fewer errors.
Payroll

UZIO Payroll starts with clean setup so every run is predictable. You define pay groups and pay schedules (weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, etc.), pick first pay dates, and make sure your payroll calendar aligns with benefits cut-offs so per-pay-period deductions calculate correctly. Once company and banking details are in place, this foundation prevents most downstream errors and makes reviews faster.

Running payroll follows a guided flow: load hours and earnings, review taxes and net pay, then approve. You can handle regular payrolls and special/off-cycle runs (e.g., bonuses or corrections), and a recent enhancement lets admins process regular and special payrolls at the same time when timelines are tight. The system also documents how bank holidays impact timing so you can plan approvals and fundings with confidence.

Admins can fine-tune results without breaking auditability. Common tasks include salary proration, overriding deduction/contribution methods, and making targeted employee payroll updates (earnings, deductions, contributions, direct-deposit changes for employees without portal access, etc.). These controls help you correct edge cases in the current cycle while keeping the underlying setup stable for future runs.

Taxes and year-end are built into the flow. UZIO documents how tax payments (impounds) are scheduled and debited relative to check dates and due dates, so finance teams can reconcile cash movement. On the employee side, the help center explains the W-2 form and provides guidance for downloading W-2s, with updates noting mobile access to W-2s as well. For bonuses or gift cards, gross-up tools calculate the necessary tax to land a target net.

Accounting and reporting close the loop. UZIO offers a two-way QuickBooks Online integration with per-component mapping (earnings, employee deductions, employer taxes/contributions) and clear syncing rules (e.g., sync after approval). Finance users can also build custom payroll reports from the Reports tab to analyze costs, taxes, and liabilities over time. Together, these features reduce spreadsheets, keep the ledger in sync, and make audits straightforward.
HR Onboarding

UZIO’s Hire & Onboarding brings candidates into your system with minimal back-and-forth. You can add a prospective employee, choose whether the employer completes the forms or send a self-onboarding invite so the candidate fills in their details, and then track progress from a single status view. This two-path approach (employer-driven or self-service) keeps momentum up while giving admins full visibility.

On the Hiring side, you can configure offer letters and supplemental documents (handbooks, policies) once and reuse them across roles. If your workflow includes screening, UZIO documents an integration with Checkr for background checks, and for work authorization, there’s a built-in integration with Clear I-9 to manage I-9/E-Verify for onsite or remote hires. These pieces reduce manual steps and keep sensitive compliance tasks inside one flow.

The Documents area acts as your onboarding content library. Admins can add custom employee documents, organize them with custom categories, and point managers to the exact place to upload or assign paperwork from the employer portal.

UZIO’s Tasks make the process trackable. A task is simply a to-do with a due date and owner; your Task Library centralizes onboarding, offboarding, and ongoing tasks so you can reuse checklists. Set up onboarding/offboarding task lists in settings, assign them to the right people, and monitor completion as part of each hire’s status—no spreadsheets required.
Benefits

UZIO’s Benefits module digitizes the entire benefits lifecycle for employers, brokers, and employees—so you can configure plans, publish packages, and manage changes year-round without paper forms. Employers get a guided setup to approve and share benefit packages, while brokers manage plan design and servicing across their book. Employees enroll online and can update coverage when eligible (new hire, open enrollment, or life events).

Plan building is structured and reusable. You can load plans and rates (medical, dental, vision, etc.), define eligibility classes (grouping by role/location), and set contribution strategies (fixed dollar, percent, tiers for dependents). A Decision Support System (DSS) helps compare plan designs so you can present the right mix by cost and coverage before publishing packages.

Enrollment is built for real life. Admins can run new-hire enrollments, open enrollment, and mid-year enrollments when adding clients or moving groups mid-cycle. The Enrollments dashboard shows participation and completion status, and product updates.

Renewals are streamlined. At plan year change, you can roll over coverage and select replacement plans where necessary—then monitor the impact through Enrollment and Financial dashboards for cost visibility. On the employee side, help articles confirm that workers enroll from the portal and can access their elections and premiums at any time; mobile FAQs reinforce that eligibility and enrollment happen through the employee portal.
Finally, benefits data doesn’t live in silo. UZIO payroll system automatically pulls the deductions and contributions from the benefits and process in the payroll.
Accessible Platforms
Employer Portal

Employer Portal is the command center for admins and managers. From here you can run payroll, review and approve time sheets, manage time and break rules, and keep an eye on benefits via Enrollment and Financial dashboards. Admins can also manage user access (e.g., limit employer users to specific work locations) and handle everyday HR tasks like adding or terminating employees. This portal is where setup decisions (pay schedules, policies, roles) turn into day-to-day actions.
Employee Portal

Employee Portal gives every worker a single place to use time tracking, request and manager time off, complete benefits enrollment, see pay stubs and W-2s and update tax withholding details and direct-deposit details on the web. It also includes documents and task completions, view the historical data of benefits and self-service help for login and password resets so employees can get back in quickly without HR intervention. This keeps payroll and HR data accurate at the source while reducing back-and-forth with administrators.
UZIO Mobile App

On the go, employees can do the essentials from the UZIO Mobile App: clock in/out and track breaks, view pay stubs, check balances and request time off, view and manage schedule, and (if enabled) manage timesheets and time off for direct reports. It’s the same data as the web portals, optimized for quick actions from a phone.
UZIO Kiosk

For shared worksites, the browser-based Time Kiosk lets employees clock in/out, take meal/rest breaks, and interact with assigned shifts on a common device. Employers configure the kiosk and link it to the right location/policy set, giving frontline teams a simple way to capture accurate time without individual smartphones.
Account Setup
Setting Up Employer Account

Registration email: New employer admins receive a “Register Now” email when UZIO support team add their company in the UZIO system. Click the link to set your username and password and complete the employer profile.
Add additional admins/managers: Go to Manage Users to create roles and grant access (e.g., Payroll Admin, HR Manager) to users of these roles. You can limit access by function or location.
Setting Up Employee Account
Invite & self-registration: Employees typically receive an email with a registration link to create their username and password (employee self-service).
The new hire gets the registration email when they are invited for self-onboarding.
The existing employees gets the registration email as soon as they are added into the list of onboarded employees.
Login as Employer
Go to uzio.com and choose Employer from the login drop-down to reach the employer sign-in page. If you have already registered, log in with your credentials.
Forgot password? Use the “Need help logging in?” link on the login screen to reset your password securely.
Login as Employee
Access the Employee login from the same drop-down on uzio.com (or from your employer’s invite link), then sign in with the username/password you created during setup.
If you can’t sign in, click Need help logging in? to reset your password; once login, you can manage pay stubs, W-2s, direct deposit, time off, and time tracking as enabled by your employer.

UZIO Scheduling
Getting Started
Introduction to Scheduling

The objective of this article is to empower users with the knowledge and tools to effectively use Uzio's Shift and Scheduling feature. This tool streamlines workforce management, ensuring efficient and fair work hour distribution while enhancing employee satisfaction. The article provides clear instructions for setting up and managing schedules, helping administrators maximize productivity and reduce administrative tasks.
Enable Scheduling

Before you start using the Shift and Scheduling feature on your account, please ensure that you have subscribed to the scheduling feature in conjunction with time tracking. If you are already subscribed, then you are all set to use this functionality. If not, please drop a note at support@uzio.com. Our team will reach out to you and share the plan details, and provide a live demo if required, before you subscribe to the feature.
Configuring Scheduling

Unlike time tracking, there is no initial setup required for using scheduling after getting enabled by the UZIO team. If you need you can configure some optional settings of scheduling by opening Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation and going to Schedule.
How to Access Scheduling Features?

Log in to the Uzio employer portal. In the left menu under the Time Tracking section, you will see "Schedule." Click on that to access the scheduling feature. From here, you can effortlessly create and manage your employees' schedules.
Who Can Manage Scheduling Settings?

Employer administrators or any user in the company who has been granted edit access to the company-level permissions for the "Schedule and Time Tracking" can manage the Schedule settings and notifications for the company. To grant this permission follow the steps
Login as Employer Admin.
Open Manage Users from the left navigation menu
Locate or add the role and go to Company Access and find the setting Schedule and Time Tracking Settings.
Set the permissions as required
No Access- No access to manage schedule and time tracking settings.
View Access- View access to schedule and time tracking settings. Means cannot add employee, manage Overtime or break rules, manage geofence, schedule settings or time tracking settings.

Full Access- Full access to schedule and time tracking settings. Means the user can add employees for time tracking and scheduling, manage Overtime or break rules, manage geofence, schedule settings or time tracking settings.
Who Can Create and Manage Shifts?
Employer administrators or any user in the company who has been granted edit access to the employee-level permissions for the "Employee Schedule" can manage shifts of the accessible employees.
No Access- The user cannot view the employee schedule.

View Access- The user can view the employee schedule but cannot add, edit, delete, copy, import or approve shifts. It means the view only actions are available to the user but the user cannot perform any transaction.
Full Access- The user can view  as well as add, edit, delete, copy, import or approve shifts.
Who is Visible by Default for Scheduling?

All employees, regardless of their pay type (hourly or salaried), who are selected for time tracking are by default visible in the scheduling module. You can create and manage their shifts. If you want to add or remove any employee from scheduling, follow the steps
Login as Employer User
Open "Time Settings" from the left navigation
Go to Employees Tab
Select “Select Employees” to add the employee for Time Tracking ans Scheduling
Select “Remove Employee” action to remove the employee from time tracking and scheduling.
Scheduling Grid and Its Key Features

The Scheduling grid is a tabular layout where employer users can easily view employee shifts either by their name or work location for the selected day, week, or month. Within this grid, employer users can take several actions on individual shifts as well as on groups of shifts, such as the entire schedule.
Filter
Use the grid’s filter panel to refine which shifts you see. You can filter by
Work Location
Department
Job Title
Pay Group
Pay Type
Employment Type

You may combine multiple filters at once to narrow results to a specific segment (e.g., “Hourly staff at Station 1 work location”). Filters remain in effect until you clear them, and the grid updates in real time.
Search

A Search box is also available to find shifts for a specific employee by name; search is applied on top of any active filters, so you can, for example, search “John” within “Retail • Part-Time • Chicago” to see only matching rows.
Different Views of Scheduler grid
The system provides multiple views of the scheduler grid and also facilitates the user to view the shifts of the desired employees.
Week

By default, the grid opens to the current week, with the week range shown at the top. Use the Left/Right arrows to move to earlier or later weeks; any active filters and search remain applied as you navigate. The layout is weekly: each column is a day (Mon–Sun), and each row represents a scope you choose—Employee, Work Location, or Job—so you can review coverage from different angles and drill into specific needs.
Employee view: Each row is an employee; every cell shows that person’s shifts for the date in the column. Multiple shifts stack in the cell.
Work Location view: Each row is a location; every cell lists shifts of all employees scheduled at that location, for the date.
Job view: Each row is a job; every cell shows all shifts tied to that job for the date, across locations. The row “Uncategorised Job” shows the shifts that are not tagged with any job.
Month

The grid displays a monthly layout, where each cell represents a calendar day in the selected month. By default the current month opens. Within each day’s cell, the system lists all scheduled employee shifts for that date, allowing you to scan coverage and identify gaps at a glance. Use the Previous/Next arrows to move between months; your active filters and search criteria remain applied as you navigate.
Day
By default, it opens today. You can move to the previous or next day using the arrow controls; your active filters and search criteria remain applied as you navigate.

The layout is daily: The grid uses a daily timeline with 12 columns, one for each 2 hours of the day.  The column starts from 00:00 Hours and ends at 22:00 Hours. Each row represents a scope you choose—Employee, Work Location, or Job—so you can review coverage from different angles and drill into specific needs. Shifts are rendered as horizontal bars spanning the relevant hours—e.g., a 9:00 AM–5:00 PM shift covers eight columns from 9 through 17.
Employee view: Each row is an employee; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for that employee on the selected day.
Work Location view: Each row is a location; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for all employees of the location on the selected day.

Job view: Each row is a job; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for all employees which are tagged with the respective job on the selected day. The row “Uncategorised Job” shows the shifts that are not tagged with any job.
Show/Hide Cost

With the help of this feature, you can estimate the total cost of the assigned shifts. In the Day and Week view of the scheduler, the total cost appears on the bottom of each column. The total cost does not appear in the month view. You can show or hide the cost with the help of the actions “Show Cost”/”Hide Cost” from the action menu on the scheduler. How the cost is calculated

If the shift is associated with a job, then the total cost of a shift is calculated by the no. of hours of the shift multiplied by the employee’s hourly pay rate of the respective job for the respective employee.

If the shift is not associated with any job, then the total cost of a shift is calculated by the no. of hours of the shift multiplied by the employee’s hourly pay rate of the primary job (shown on the Job Page of the employee profile).
Show/Hide Hours

With the help of this feature, you can estimate the total hours of the assigned shifts. In the  Day and Week view of the scheduler, the total hours appear on the bottom of each column. The total hours do not appear in the month view. You can show or hide the hours with the help of the actions “Show Hours”/”Hide Hours” from the action menu on the scheduler. To calculate the total hours, sum up the hours of all the shifts showing in the column.
Wages/Hours Budget

Scheduling managers will be able to set daily and weekly budgets for each work location by selecting “Wages/Hours Budget” from the Actions dropdown. While creating schedules, managers will be able to compare the estimated schedule costs with the set budget, ensuring better cost control.
Creating Shift

Creating shifts on the “Schedule” page is a straightforward, quick, and intuitive process. To create a shift, you have two options: either double-click any cell within the scheduler or click the plus icon that appears when you hover over the cell. Once you initiate this shift creation action, the system will open the "Add Shift" window to capture the key attributes of the shift
Creating Shift for specific employee

If you want to create a shift for a specific employee then under the input “Assignee” select “By Employees” and under the input “Employees” search for the employee for whom you want to create a shift.
Creating Shift in bulk
To create shifts in bulk for multiple employees, UZIO allows you to generate them by Work Location, Department, or Pay Type, making scheduling faster and more efficient.

Under the “Assignee” field, select the desired grouping option — Department, Pay Type, or Work Location. Once selected, choose the specific values (for example, the departments or locations) for which you want to create shifts.

The system then automatically creates shifts for all active employees belonging to the selected departments, locations, or pay types who are already enabled for time tracking. This ensures that shifts are consistently applied across large groups without the need to manually create them one by one.
Time In/Time Out
Date and time of shift start and shift end.
Project/Job

You can tag a job—either part of a project or a standalone role—to a specific shift to ensure accurate job tracking. When a job is tagged to a shift, the employee is required to work under that job only while clocking in. The system automatically restricts them from selecting any other job during that shift, helping maintain accountability and reporting accuracy.

If you choose not to tag a job to a shift, employees will have the flexibility to select the appropriate job manually at clock-in, based on their task or assignment for the day. This setup gives employers the choice between strict job assignment control and flexible job selection, depending on operational needs.
Colour
You can give a color to shift, to distinguish between shifts of different departments, locations, job profile, employee etc, as per your requirement.
Creating Shifts for Multiple Days

To create shifts for multiple days in bulk, simply enable the “Repeat Shift” checkbox while creating a new shift. Once selected, choose the “Ends On” date and specify the days of the week (e.g., Monday, Wednesday, Friday) on which you want the shift to repeat.

This feature allows you to quickly generate recurring shifts for a defined period without manually creating each one. It’s especially useful for consistent scheduling patterns, such as weekly or bi-weekly shifts, ensuring efficiency and accuracy in large-scale shift planning.
Notes

This is an optional field where you can add any additional comments or context related to the shift. It can include notes such as specific instructions, task details, reminders, or any other relevant information in text format that may help employees or managers understand the shift better.
Things to Note
Just creating a shift does not make it available to track time, you need to publish as well.
You can create shifts for any day, the system does not restrict you to create shifts on a holiday or time off day.
You can not create overlapping shifts for any employee.
You can create multiple shifts for an employee on a day.
You can create overnight shifts as well.
Creating a Multi Day Shift

Employers can create shifts which start on one day and end on another. To do so, the employer needs to enter two different dates on the Add Shift pop up. If the employer is creating a multi day shift, the system will create two separate shifts, first ending at 11:59PM and another starting at 12:00 AM.
Schedule Import
UZIO provides an additional way to create shifts in bulk through the Schedule Import feature, allowing employers to quickly generate multiple shifts at once using an Excel template.
To import shifts in bulk, follow these steps:
Navigate to Time Tracking from the left-hand menu.
Go to Schedule and click the Schedule Import icon at the top of the page.
The system will prompt you to download the Schedule Import template. Each row in this Excel sheet represents a single employee shift.

By default, the template includes all employees you have access to create shifts for, prepopulated with one shift for tomorrow. The start and end times in the sheet are based on your default shift settings under Schedule Settings.

You can modify the downloaded template to suit your needs — add or remove rows, adjust dates or timings, specify shift colors, or include notes. All shifts are created in blue color by default unless otherwise specified.

Once your updates are complete, upload the file back into the system. The upload process is asynchronous, meaning you can continue working elsewhere in UZIO while the file processes in the background. When the upload is complete, a confirmation message will appear at the top of the screen. If any issues occur, the system will provide an error file in the File Center, listing the rows and reasons for failure.
Important Notes:
You can create shifts in bulk but cannot edit them in bulk.
All imported shifts are initially created in an unpublished state — you must publish them before employees can start tracking time.
Publishing Shift
To publish shifts, you have two options depending on whether you want to publish a single shift or multiple at once.
Publishing a Specific Shift

To publish a specific shift, simply click directly on the shift in the scheduler grid and select the “Publish” action. The shift will immediately change to published status and become visible to the assigned employee for tracking.
Publishing Shift in Bulk
To publish shifts in bulk, click the “Publish” button located at the top-right corner of the scheduler grid. This action will publish all unpublished shifts currently visible on your screen.

Note: If you’ve applied filters or search criteria that limit the view (for example, by department, job, or work location), only the shifts that are currently displayed on the grid will be published. To publish all shifts across the organization, make sure to clear filters and searches before using the bulk publish option.
Overlap Detected

When publishing shifts in bulk, if the system detects that some shifts overlap with existing ones, it will publish all non-conflicting shifts and skip only the overlapping ones. After processing, UZIO will display a summary message indicating which specific shifts could not be published due to overlaps.

This helps ensure scheduling accuracy while still allowing valid shifts to go live immediately. You can review the flagged overlaps directly from the message, adjust the conflicting shifts, and then republish them once resolved.
Editing a Shift

You can edit an existing shift by clicking directly on it and selecting the “Edit” action. This opens the same window used for creating a new shift, where all shift details are displayed. From here, you can update any of the shift’s attributes—such as timing, assigned employee or job, or notes—and then save your changes. The updates take effect immediately and are reflected across all relevant schedule views.
Things to note
You can edit both published and unpublished shifts, but shifts that already have recorded time entries cannot be modified to preserve data accuracy.

While editing, you can change the shift date, but note that this effectively deletes the original shift for the current date and creates a new shift for the updated date. The system automatically enforces overlapping shift validations, ensuring that no employee is assigned two conflicting shifts for the same period.

Additionally, you can reassign the shift to another employee, allowing managers to make adjustments quickly when staffing changes occur. All updates are applied instantly and reflected in the schedule view once saved.
Deleting Shift
Deleting an Specific Shift

To delete a specific shift, simply click directly on the shift in the scheduler grid and select the “Delete” action. The shift will immediately be deleted and become unavailable to the assigned employee for tracking.
You can delete both published and unpublished shifts, but shifts that already have recorded time entries cannot be deleted to preserve data accuracy.
Deleting Entire Schedule

To delete the entire schedule, including both published and unpublished shifts, choose the “Delete Entire Schedule” option from the Action menu at the top of the scheduler grid. This action removes all shifts within the currently displayed schedule view, allowing you to clear and rebuild it if needed.

However, the system does not delete any shift that already has time tracked by an employee, to preserve historical and payroll data integrity. Once the deletion is confirmed, all eligible shifts are permanently removed, and a confirmation message appears upon completion.
This action will delete all unpublished  and published shifts currently visible on your screen.

Note: If you’ve applied filters or search criteria that limit the view (for example, by department, job, or work location), only the shifts that are currently displayed on the grid will be deleted. To delete all shifts across the organization, make sure to clear filters and searches before using the bulk delete option.
Clear Unpublished Changes

To delete only unpublished shifts, choose the “Clear Unpublished Changes” option from the Action menu at the top of the scheduler grid. This action removes all shifts within the currently displayed schedule view which are unpublished, allowing you to clear and rebuild it if needed.
However, the system does not delete any shift that already has time tracked by an employee, to preserve historical and payroll data integrity.

Note: If you’ve applied filters or search criteria that limit the view (for example, by department, job, or work location), only the shifts that are currently displayed on the grid will be deleted. To delete all shifts across the organization, make sure to clear filters and searches before using the bulk delete option.
Download Schedule
You can download the schedule in two ways- as PDF or as Excel Sheet.
Download as PDF

When you use the Download Schedule as PDF action, UZIO exports the entire scheduler grid into a PDF file for easy sharing and recordkeeping. The generated PDF includes all shift types currently displayed on the scheduler — published shifts, unpublished shifts, and open shifts.
Download as XLS

When you use the Download Schedule XLS action, UZIO exports the current schedule into an Excel file. Upon initiating this action, the system generates the report in the background and displays a confirmation message at the top of the screen with a download link once the file is ready.

When exporting the schedule, UZIO automatically runs the Shift Assignment Report in the background with the selection criteria set to “By Employees.” The report includes only the employees currently visible on the scheduler grid, respecting any filters or searches applied.

You can also access and download this same report anytime from the Reports section for future reference or further analysis. This feature ensures you have a quick, organized view of all scheduled shifts in a structured Excel format.
Copy Shift

You can copy existing shifts quickly using the “Copy” icon located at the top of the scheduler grid. Once you click on it, the system will prompt you to choose one of the following options based on how you want to duplicate your schedule:
Copy to Next
Duplicates all shifts currently displayed on the scheduler grid and copies them to the next day, week, or month, depending on the active scheduler view.
Copy from Previous
Pulls shifts from the previous day, week, or month and replicates them into the current period of the scheduler grid.
Advanced Option

Gives you full flexibility to copy shifts from any prior day, week, or month to any future day, week, or month. You can select both the source and destination periods from dropdown lists to control exactly where shifts are duplicated.
This feature is especially useful for maintaining consistent scheduling patterns across periods, reducing manual effort and ensuring quick adjustments to recurring workforce plans.
Open Shift
What is Open Shift
An Open Shift is a shift that is not assigned to any specific employee and is available for eligible employees to claim.

Open shifts can be created for one or more work locations, and any active employee belonging to those locations can view and claim them based on availability. Once claimed and approved, the shift becomes assigned to that employee and follows the same tracking and approval flow as a regular shift.
Creating an Open Shift
To create an open shift, you can either double-click any cell within the scheduler grid or click the plus (+) icon that appears when you hover over a cell. This opens the shift creation window.

In the pop-up, under the “Assignee” dropdown, select “Open Shift”. Then, under the Work Location dropdown, choose one or more locations where you want the open shift to be available. If you are selecting multiple locations, the system will create one shift for each work location. Employees associated with the selected locations will be able to view and claim these shifts.
Claiming an Open Shift
Employees can claim open shifts directly from the mobile app—this functionality is not available on the web.
To claim an open shift, follow these steps:
Log in to the UZIO mobile app as an employee.
Tap Schedule from the bottom navigation bar.
Select Open Shifts and click on “Available Shifts” to view all available unassigned shifts for your work location(s).
Tap the Claim link next to the shift you wish to take.

Schedule Settings
Admin can set the following settings by the following steps
Login as Employer on the employer portal
Open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation
Go to Schedule form the right
Locate the respective settings and configure.
Prevent Early Clock In

To prevent early clock-ins, admins can configure a clock-in restriction setting. When enabled, employees are not allowed to clock in earlier than the defined threshold before their scheduled shift start time.

For example, if the threshold is set to 15 minutes and the shift starts at 9:00 AM, employees will be restricted from clocking in before 8:45 AM for that shift. This ensures that employees begin work within their authorized time window, preventing unnecessary early punches and controlling overtime costs.
However, if an employee chooses to clock in under “Unscheduled”, this restriction does not apply — allowing flexibility for situations where employees are working outside their scheduled shifts.
Mark Late Clock In

To flag a time entry as “Late”, admins can enable the late clock-in setting. When this is configured, the system automatically flags any time entry where an employee clocks in after the defined threshold from their scheduled shift start time.

For example, if the threshold is set to 15 minutes and the shift starts at 9:00 AM, any clock-in after 9:15 AM for that shift will be marked as “Late.” This feature helps maintain punctuality, provides better visibility into attendance patterns, and ensures accurate reporting for performance or compliance tracking.
Default Shift Timings

To define default shift timings, the admin can configure this setting. Once set, these timings automatically prepopulate when creating a new shift, saving time and maintaining consistency across the schedule.

For example, if the default shift time is set as 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM, these hours will appear by default in the shift creation window. However, users can still modify the timings as needed for specific employees or situations before saving the shift.

UZIO Time Tracking
Getting Started
Introduction to UZIO Time Tracking

UZIO Time Tracking provides a centralized, compliant system for capturing employee work hours across Web, Mobile, and Kiosk. Administrators can configure overtime, double-time, and seventh-day rules; define paid and unpaid breaks with eligibility windows, guardrails, and premiums; enforce geofencing, scheduling, various notifications and time tracking settings. Role-based permissions govern who can manage employer level action of time tracking and who can manage employee timesheets. Approved timesheets are finalized by approving hours and syncing to payroll, ensuring timely and correct pay.
Enable Time Tracking

Time Tracking is an add-on. Submit a request from the employer portal; UZIO will enable it for your account. Employer Admins or other employer users who have the full access to company level “Scheduling and Time Tracking” permission can request to enable the Time Tracking module on the UZIO. Follow the steps below to enable-
Sign in to the employer portal.
From the left navigation, open Time Tracking.
Click “I am Interested” to send the activation request.
UZIO reviews and enables for you.
Log out and Login back in to load the module.
Once UZIO enables it, you’ll see “Schedule and Time Tracking” in the left navigation. It's time to configure the time tracking.
Configuring Time Tracking

Configuring Time Tracking is a one-time, guided setup available after UZIO enables the module. Sign in to the employer portal, open Time Tracking from the left navigation, and click Get Started, then complete the following steps-
Adding Employees

Begin by adding employees to Time Tracking. Click Select Employees to open the selector, search or filter as needed, and choose the employees to include; confirm to add them to your Time Tracking list.
Prerequisite: Each employee that you are about to add, must be assigned to a pay group with an active payroll calendar—employees without a calendar will not be allowed for selection.
Overtime Rules Assignment

Set how overtime is calculated, then assign the rule to the employees who need it. UZIO includes a built-in Default rule—workweek starts Sunday, weekly overtime at 40 hours, and no seventh-consecutive-day rule—and all employees are mapped to this by default.

If your policy differs, click Add Overtime Rule, enter your parameters (workweek start day, weekly OT threshold, optional daily OT/double-time thresholds, and seventh-day treatment), save, and then assign the new rule to the relevant employees.
Note: Overtime rules apply to non-exempt employees. Exempt salaried employees are typically excluded by company policy.
Break Rule Assignment

Define how employees take and record breaks by creating Break Rules. These rules specify which break types are allowed (paid rest, unpaid meal), their durations, timing windows, and any compliance checks.
No break rules exist by default—and employees cannot record breaks until at least one rule is created and assigned to them.
Click Add Break Rule, configure the policy details, save, and assign it to the appropriate employees or groups.
Geofence Setup

Set location-based clocking boundaries with Geofencing. Define an allowed area around each work location so the system can detect whether employees clock in/out inside or outside that zone. You can choose to restrict punches outside the geofence (block them) or allow but flag them for review. This helps prevent off-site punches and improves the accuracy of time capture.
Select the work location, edit it, enable the geofence and set the geofence radius/area on the map, and save.
Schedule Settings
Configure Scheduling only if the Scheduling module is enabled (it becomes available after Time Tracking is enabled).

In this step, review and set your scheduling preferences—choose how and when employees are notified about shifts (publish, reminders before start/end, early/late clock windows) and adjust any general scheduling defaults.
Save your changes to apply them across the roster.
Time Clocks
Finish by choosing how employees will record time. Enable one or more capture modes—Web, Mobile, and/or Kiosk—based on your environment, then apply the settings to the relevant employees or groups.

For Web, confirm whether punches are allowed or not.For Mobile, confirm whether geofence checks should be enforced at punch time. For Kiosk, create a kiosk station and decide login method and photo security.

After you choose the time clocks, configure the General controls for how time is managed. Decide whether employees can add, edit, or delete their own entries; if allowed, specify whether manager approval is required for any manual add/edit. Require a note whenever an employee or manager changes a time entry, and choose whether employees can view change history. Turn on employee attestation if you want workers to confirm their entries, select the time display format (12-hour or 24-hour), and set the Missing Clock-Out flag to trigger after a defined number of hours from start. Finally, set notifications (Email/SMS/Push) for long-running entries—configure a first and second reminder—and a reminder for missed attestation. Click Save and Publish to apply your settings.
Now your employees are all set to start tracking time.
Roles and Permissions for using Time Tracking

Employer users can perform Time Tracking actions only if their assigned role allows it. What each person can see or do—such as adding entries, editing, approving, running reports or making modifications in the time tracking settings—is determined by the permissions linked to their role. If a permission isn’t granted on the role, the action won’t be available to that user. Employer Administrator can view and manage permissions of the assigned role by navigating as follows
Log in as Employer -> Locate Manage Users in the Left Navigation  -> Locate the role.
Managing Employer Settings of Time Tracking

To view or manage company-level Time Tracking items—such as adding employees to Time Tracking, configuring overtime and break rules, setting schedules, defining geofences for work locations, and other settings—open the user’s Role in the Manage User from the left navigation, go to Company Access, and find Schedule & Time Tracking. It may have three possible values

No Access: Choose this when the user should have no company-level visibility or control in Time Tracking. They won’t be able to open a Time Tracking Setting page or see any company settings, and they cannot add employees, edit rules, manage schedules, or adjust geofences. (This does not stop them from using personal timesheet features if those are granted access.)

View Only-  Choose this when the user should see company-level Time Tracking settings but not change anything. They can open pages that show who’s enabled for Time Tracking, the current overtime and break rules, schedules, geofences and other time tracking settings—but all actions are read-only (no add, edit, or delete).

Full Access-  Choose this when the user needs to view and update company-level Time Tracking. They can add employees to Time Tracking, create or modify overtime and break rules, manage schedules, set or change geofences for locations, and adjust other configuration settings.
Managing Employee Timesheet

To view or manage timesheets of accessible employees, open the user’s Role in the Manage User from the left navigation, go to Employee Access, and find the Employee Timesheet under Additional Information. You can manage the ability to view/edit and approve timesheets via this permission. It may have three possible values

No Access- Choose this when the user should have no visibility of employees timesheets of accessible employees. The user will no longer see the employee on the Employee’s Timesheet page. This does not stop them from using personal timesheet features if those are granted access.
View Only-  Choose this when the user should see the employee's timesheet of accessible employees but not make modifications in the employee timesheet.
Full Access-  Choose this when the user needs to view and update the employee's timesheet of accessible employees.

Overtime Rule Management

This section describes how UZIO lets you configure, assign, update, and control overtime policies in one place. It covers creating overtime rules (workweek start, weekly OT, daily OT, daily double-time, 7th consecutive day OT), assigning them to the right employees in bulk, and editing them prospectively so historical calculations remain unchanged. It also defines when an overtime rule can be deleted (only if it is not assigned), ensuring consistent, compliant, and auditable overtime processing.
Creating Overtime Rules
UZIO provides the ability to configure rules to calculate overtime and double overtime hours for the hourly employees. You can do so by creating an "Overtime Rule”. To create an overtime rule
Open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation
Go to the Overtime Rules tab
Click on the “Add Overtime Rule”. The rules has following information
Rule Name
You can give any customized alphanumeric name to the rule.
Workweek Start Day

The workweek start day sets the window for calculating weekly overtime. If you choose Sunday as the start, each W-2-eligible employee’s weekly pay period runs Sunday through Saturday, and overtime is measured within that exact window.
Weekly Overtime Start After Hours

You can set the total hours in a workweek after which all additional hours are paid at the overtime rate. Hours worked beyond this weekly threshold are paid at an overtime premium of 1.5× the employee’s regular rate of pay.  Example: If the weekly threshold is set to 40 hours and an employee works 46 hours in the workweek, the first 40 hours are paid at the regular rate. The remaining 6 hours are paid at the overtime rate of 1.5×.
Daily Overtime Start After Hours

You can set the total number of hours in a single workday after which additional hours are paid at the overtime rate. All hours worked beyond the weekly threshold are paid at an overtime rate of 1.5× the employee’s regular hourly rate. Example: If daily overtime begins after 8 hours and an employee works 9.5 hours on Tuesday, the first 8 hours are paid at the regular rate. The additional 1.5 hours that day are paid at 1.5×.
Daily Double Overtime Start After Hours

You can set the total number of hours in a single workday after which additional hours are paid at the double overtime rate. All hours worked beyond the weekly threshold are paid at an overtime rate of 2× the employee’s regular hourly rate. Example: If daily overtime begins after 8 hours and double time begins after 12 hours, and an employee works 13 hours on Friday, pay the first 8 hours at the regular rate, hours 9–12 at 1.5×, and hour 13 at 2×.
7th Consecutive Day Overtime

In certain states, when a non-exempt employee works seven consecutive days in the same workweek, the hours worked on the seventh day must be paid at an overtime premium of 1.5× the employee’s regular hourly rate (subject to local law and your company policy). Configure the 7th Consecutive Day option in your overtime settings to apply this automatically. Example: If the workweek runs Sunday through Saturday and an employee works all seven days, the seventh day becomes overtime-eligible. For example, if they work 6 hours on Day 7, those 6 hours are paid at 1.5× (and, if your policy/state requires it, hours beyond 8 on Day 7 would be paid at 2×).
Assign To
You can assign the overtime rules in bulk. Select the employees to whom the rule applies.

Go to Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation

This means any older entries that were already evaluated for Overtime hours or Double overtime hours will remain exactly as they were under the original settings. Only time entries created or edited after the update will use the revised rule. This protects historical records and prevents retroactive payroll changes.

Overtime Pay

Overtime pay, as described by the FLSA (Fair Labor Standards Act) is awarded to non-exempt employees who qualify for overtime pay. Overtime pay for non-exempt employees is calculated at one-and-a-half times (1.5x) their hourly rate, for every work hour beyond the standard 40-hour week. Once you have determined overtime eligibility, calculating overtime pay is simple.
What is Blended Rates of Overtime Pay

The federal government’s Fair Labor Standards Act requires that when work is performed at two or more rates, overtime must be paid out at a blended rate. A “blended rate” is a rate of not less than one-and-a-half times the weighted average of all non-overtime rates used during that workweek.
When is a Blended Rate Required?

For most employers, calculating overtime is straightforward: employees receive one-and-a-half times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over 40 hours. However, this becomes more complicated for employers that have employees that work different jobs at different rates. You may have employees that perform different jobs or tasks at different rates.
Weighted vs Blended Overtime - Are They the Same?
Yes, blended overtime is often referred to as weighted or weighted average. It gets its name because a weighted average of two different pay rates is used to determine the overtime rate.

Step 2: Divide the total straight wage calculated in Step 1 by total work (Regular + OT + DOT) hours to find blended rate.

Break Management

This section describes how UZIO lets you define, assign, and control break policies in a centralized, consistent way. It covers creating Break Rules (paid vs unpaid, eligibility windows, durations, guardrails like prevent early/short breaks, auto-end, and missed/short/long-break handling), assigning them to the right employees or groups, and configuring options such as premiums, notifications, and break attestation.
Creating  Break Rules

Break Rules define your paid rest and unpaid meal policies—types, durations, timing windows, eligibility. UZIO does not create break rules automatically; employees cannot record breaks until a rule is created and assigned.It’s recommended to configure rules to match state/industry laws—this improves compliance, creates a consistent employee experience, and reduces payroll disputes.
You can configure break policies by creating "Break Rule”. To create a break rule, Open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation
Go to the Break Rules tab
Click on the “Add Break Rule”.
The following information is mandatory to create a break
Break Code
An alphanumeric break code to uniquely identify a break in your organization.
Break Name
An alphanumeric break name that employees will see while punched in.
Break Category
UZIO supports two break categories - Meal and Rest. You can create multiple breaks under each category. A break category is used to group the same kind of break under one category.
Break Type
UZIO supports two break types: Paid and Unpaid.
Paid Breaks- These are considered working hours, meaning employees are compensated for this time. They are also factored into calculations for overtime and double-time pay.
Unpaid Breaks- These are not considered working hours, are not compensated, and are excluded from all overtime and double-time calculations.
Break Duration

Enter the break duration in minutes. UZIO uses this value to evaluate exceptions—such as short or long breaks—to auto-end breaks when they exceed limits, and to prevent short breaks when guardrails are enabled. The duration also drives break notifications (for reminders alerts). If the Prevent Early Break guardrail is not configured, employees can end a break shorter or longer than the set duration.
Break Eligibility Window
Break Eligibility window is the minimum working time an employee must complete in a shift before a break becomes due. UZIO supports two settings to define the break eligibility windows.
Employees receive a break if they work more than ___ hours and ___ minutes

This setting defines the first break eligibility window. UZIO does not prevent the employee from taking the break before the eligible window. When an employee works more than continuous X hours Y minutes, UZIO marks the break as eligible, if not taken, allowing the system to flag a missed break and calculate any configured premium.

Example
If the threshold is 5 hours 0 minutes, an employee becomes eligible for the break after 5:00:00 of worked time. If they don’t start a break before 5 hours, UZIO can send notifications and, based on your rules, record it like a missed break.
Repeat break for every __ hours and ___ minutes
This setting defines the subsequent break eligibility windows. The functionality remains the same as defined above.
Resolving Missed Breaks

The Resolving Missed Breaks section controls what UZIO should do when an employee does not take a break within the eligible window. Here you choose whether the system auto-deducts a missed break or simply flags it for review, sets the point at which a break is auto inserted or flagged as missed, and defines any premium to award for each missed break. You can also require break attestation so employees or managers record a reason when a break is missed. These settings ensure missed breaks are handled consistently for payroll, compliance, and audit purposes.
Auto Deduct/Flag
Choose the automatic action UZIO takes when a break isn’t taken within the eligible window.
Deduct Missing Break - The system inserts a missed-break deduction into the time entry (per your rule’s duration/type), which adjusts worked time and payroll totals accordingly.
Flag Missing Break - The system does not change the time entry but adds a missed-break for review and follow-up.
Deduct/Flag Missing Break at
Choose at what time, UZIO should place or flag the missed-break inside the time entry when a break isn’t taken within the eligible window.

Starting of Time Entry — Inserts or flags the missed break at the start time of the eligible window. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be inserted or flagged from 9AM to 9:30 AM.

Middle of Time Entry — Inserts or flags the missed break at the midpoint of the eligible window. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be Inserted or flagged from 11:30AM to 12:00 AM.

End of Time Entry — Inserts or flags the missed break at end of the eligible window.Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be Inserted or flagged from 1:30PM to 2:00 PM.

Custom Hours — Inserts or flags the missed break at a specific offset from the start (e.g., at 1:00 hours). Use this when policy requires the missed break to be recorded at a specific time. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes and the custom time defined in this setting is 1 Hour, the missed break will be Inserted or flagged from 10 AM to 10:30 AM.
Break Premium

Use the setting Award a premium of __ hours and ___ minutes for each missed break to automatically add extra paid time to the time entry whenever a break is missed. Enter the premium duration (hours and minutes); the amount is applied per missed break and added to paid time, and sent to payroll with the designated earning code. The system applies the capping of 1 Hour on the total no. of premium hours per break category per time entry.
Example: If the premium is 1hour and two breaks are missed, the entry receives 2 hours of premium pay but since it is capped at 1 hour, so the final premium would be 1 hour.
Break Attestation

When the setting Break Attestation Required is enabled, UZIO evaluates at clock-out whether the employee took the break within the eligible window. If not, the employee sees an attestation prompt. For each missed break, they can choose one of three actions:
Add the break to the time entry (insert the missed break per your rule) by selecting the choice “Yes, I took this break.”,
Confirm it was missed due to work by selecting “No, I was prevented by work from taking this break.”
Confirm it was missed by choice by selecting “I had the opportunity, but I freely chose not to take this break.”
UZIO records the selection (and any notes) on the time entry for audit/compliance and applies your policy—such as premiums —accordingly.
Break Guardrails
Prevent starting early breaks

Use the setting Allow break only after __ hours __ minutes from the start of the time entry to prevent starting an early break. Sets a minimum wait time before a break can start. Employees cannot begin this break until X hours Y minutes have elapsed from the clock-in time; the system shows a validation on taking the break before that point.
Example: If set to 2 hours 0 minutes and the shift starts at 9:00 AM, the break can’t start before 11:00 AM.
Prevent Early Break End.
Use this guardrail to block early break endings. When enabled, an employee cannot end a break before the scheduled duration has elapsed.
Example: If the break duration is 30 minutes and the break starts at 9:30 AM, the system will not allow the employee to end it before 10:00 AM.
Automatically end break when duration ends

Use this guardrail to end the break automatically when the scheduled end time (Start time +Duration) is reached. It ensures compliance with Short Break. Example: Break starts at 9:30 AM, duration 30 minutes (scheduled end 10:00 AM). Break will automatically end at 10AM.
Short Break

Use the guardrail Flag Break as Short if break ends before __ minutes to flag a break as “Short” when an employee ends it too early relative to its scheduled end time (start time + duration). You set an early-end variance in minutes; if the break ends earlier than scheduled end − variance, UZIO marks it as Short.
Example: Break starts at 9:30 AM, duration 30 minutes (scheduled end 10:00 AM), variance 10 minutes. If the employee ends the break before 9:50 AM, the system flags it as a Short Break.
Long Break

Use the guardrail Flag Break as Long if break ends after__ minutes to flag a break as “Long” when an employee ends it late relative to its scheduled end time (start time + duration). You set a late-end variance in minutes; if the break ends after the scheduled end + variance, UZIO marks it as Long.
Example: Break starts at 9:30 AM, duration 30 minutes (scheduled end 10:00 AM), variance 10 minutes. If the employee ends the break after 10:10 AM, the system flags it as a Long Break.
Break Notifications for Employees
Break Start Notification

Use the setting Email/SMS/PUSH notifications ___ minutes before the break start time to send the start break notification.If an employee hasn’t started the break by the end of the eligible window, UZIO can send a “Start Break” reminder so the full break still fits within the window. You choose the channels—Email, SMS, and/or Mobile Push—and a lead time (minutes) before the window ends. The reminder time is calculated as: window end time minus break duration minus lead time.

Example: Break duration = 30 min, eligible window = 9:00 AM–2:00 PM, lead time = 10 min. A reminder is sent at 2:00 PM − 30 min − 10 min = 1:20 PM, ensuring the employee can take a full 30-minute break and finish by 2:00 PM.

You're eligible for Meal Break in next 10 minutes at 01:30 PM. Please take your scheduled break to stay compliant with work hour guidelines.Click here to login.

Break End Notification

Use the setting Email/SMS/PUSH notifications ___ minutes before the break end time to send the start break notification. If an employee has started the break, UZIO can send an “End Break” reminder so the employee does not miss to end the break within time. You choose the channels—Email, SMS, and/or Mobile Push—and a lead time (minutes) before the duration ends. The reminder time is calculated as: Break Start time + Duration defined in the break minus lead time.

Example: Break duration = 30 min, Break started at 1:30 PM, Duration =30 Mins, lead time = 10 min. A reminder is sent at 01:30 PM + 30 Mins - 10 Mins= 1:50 PM, ensuring the employee can end the break on time.

Missed Break Handling and  Break Premiums calculations
What is Missed Break
A break is considered as missed when the employee did not take it in the designated time frame.
Missed Break Handling
To calculate the missed break of a time entry, the system uses the following two settings at the break rule level.
Employees receive a break if they work more than ___ hours and ___ minutes

This setting defines the first break eligibility window. These are the minimum working time an employee must complete in a shift before a break becomes due. UZIO does not prevent the employee from taking the break before the eligible window. When an employee works more than continuous X hours Y minutes, UZIO considers the break as eligible, if not taken, allowing the system to consider it as Missed.

Example
If the threshold is 5 hours 0 minutes, an employee becomes eligible for the break after 5 hours of worked time. If they don’t start a break before 5 hours, UZIO can send notifications and, based on your rules, consider it like a missed break.
Repeat break for every __ hours and ___ minutes
This setting defines the subsequent break eligibility windows The functionality remains same as defined above.
What happens with a missed break
When a break is determined as missed at clock out, the system can perform following operations as per the break configuration
Break Attestation by employee

When this option is enabled at break setup, UZIO evaluates at clock-out whether the employee took the break within the eligible window. If not, the employee sees an attestation prompt. For each missed break, they can choose one of three actions:
Add the break to the time entry (insert the missed break per your rule) by selecting the choice “Yes, I took this break.”,
Confirm it was missed due to work by selecting “No, I was prevented by work from taking this break.”
Confirm it was missed by choice by selecting “I had the opportunity, but I freely chose not to take this break.”
Flag as Missed Break-

If a break is configured to be handled without attestation, UZIO automatically marks it as “Missed” on the time entry. The flag is placed at the position you set under the “Deduct/Flag Missing Break at” setting in the break setup. No prompt is shown to the employee; the entry is simply flagged for review, and any configured premiums are applied
Auto Deduct

If a break is configured to be auto-deducted, UZIO automatically inserts the break into the time entry according to the break rule. The insertion occurs at the configured position/time and adjusts worked totals and payroll (paid vs. unpaid) accordingly—no employee action is required.
Position of Missed Break or Auto Deducted break
System place or flag the missed-break inside the time entry when a break isn’t taken within the eligible window.

Starting of Time Entry — Places or flags the missed break at the start time of the eligible window. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be placed or flagged from 9AM to 9:30 AM.

Middle of Time Entry — Places or flags the missed break at the midpoint of the eligible window. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be placed or flagged from 11:30AM to 12:00 AM.

End of Time Entry — Places or flags the missed break at end of the eligible window.Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes, the missed break will be placed or flagged from 1:30PM to 2:00 PM.

Custom Hours — Flags the missed break at a specific offset from the start (e.g., at 1 hour). Use this when policy requires the missed break to be recorded at a specific time. Example- If the eligible window of the break is 9AM to 2PM and the break duration is 30 Minutes and the custom time defined in this setting is 1 Hour, the missed break will be placed or flagged from 10 AM to 10:30 AM.

This gives employer users flexibility to override premiums when justified (e.g., manager-approved exceptions) or to apply policy as configured when recalculation is correct.

Break Premium Calculation
Short Break Premium

If your break rule setup includes a short-break premium, UZIO will calculate and apply it automatically when a break ends too early. A break is flagged as Short when the employee ends it before the scheduled end time (start + duration) minus the early-end variance you set. When that condition is met, UZIO flags the break as Short and adds the configured premium to the time entry and payroll totals.
Example: Break starts at 9:30 AM, duration 30 minutes (scheduled end 10:00 AM), variance 10 minutes. If the employee ends the break before 9:50 AM, the system flags it as a Short Break.
Missed Break Premium

If your break rule setup includes a missed-break premium, UZIO will calculate and add the premium automatically whenever a break is missed. The premium amount (hours/minutes) is applied per missed break and reflected in payroll totals.
Break Premium Capping

UZIO automatically adds premium paid time to the time entry when a break is missed or short, as defined in your break rule. A cap of 1 hour applies to the total premium per break category, per time entry.

Example: If the premium is 1hour per violation and two breaks are missed in the same entry, the calculated premium would be 2 hours. Because the category cap is 1 hour, the final premium applied is 1hour. The capped premium is reflected in payroll totals.

Administrative Tools
Bulk Import Time Entries
Use Bulk Upload to import clock-ins/outs and breaks from another system so you can process payroll in UZIO without re-keying. The upload consumes a standard template and creates entries sequentially.
To start timesheet upload
Go to Employees Timesheet from the navigation menu
Click the “Time Entries Import” icon.
When prompted, download the template.

Populate the file with these columns: Employee ID, Employee Name, Entry Date, Job code, break code, Clock In, Clock Out, timezone, duration and Notes. Use the formats shown in the template (date/time).

A row may represent either a main entry, meaning the start and end time of the entry which may contain breaks inside or, a break itself. Fill the break code column only for the rows reflecting a break. Leave the break code column blank on the main entry row.
Mandatory row order

UZIO processes rows in order. Always list the parent (main) time entry first, followed immediately by its break rows. This is required so the system creates the shift before attaching its breaks.
 Example (correct):

Break: 12:30–13:00
 If a break row appears before its parent, that break will fail validation or won’t link to the correct entry.

Upload the file- After you complete and order the rows, return to “Time Entries Import”, choose the file, and submit. UZIO will import each row one by one, building the day’s timeline for each employee from the parent entry and then inserting the associated breaks.

Validations & common checks-  The system verifies required fields, date/time format, employee identity, and logical sequences (Clock In < Clock Out, Break In/Out within the parent, overlaps, etc.). It also checks for duplicates and missing parents for listed breaks.

Error handling-  If any row fails, UZIO generates an error file in the File Center. Download it to see the row number and a clear error message. Fix the file, preserve the required row order, and re-upload.

After a successful upload-  Imported entries appear on the Timesheet grid and follow your existing rules (overtime, premiums, approvals). Managers can review, approve, and—when ready—Sync Hours to Payroll so hours flow into pay calculations.
Manual Modifications in the Time Entries and approval
Manual changes to time entries (add, edit, delete) and timesheet approvals can be performed by Employer users who have Full Access to Employees Timesheet on their role.

Employee users may modify their own entries only when the setting “Allow employees to add, edit and delete their time entries” is enabled; otherwise, they can view but must request a manager to make corrections. All actions follow role permissions and are recorded in the audit trail.
Adding a Time Entry
To add a time entry
Open the Timesheet page
Click “Add Time Entry”.
A pop-up lets you choose how to enter time: Clock In/Out (enter exact start and end times, and breaks if known) or By Duration (enter the total hours/minutes when exact punches aren’t available).
Use Clock In/Out if you know the precise punch times; use By Duration for estimated work blocks or after-the-fact corrections.
Provide any required notes and save. If your policy requires it, an employee’s manually added entry will be routed to the manager for approval before it posts to the timesheet.

When you add a time entry, UZIO runs validations to ensure the record is logical and consistent. The system prevents common errors such as overlapping punches or breaks and breaks that don’t fit within the entry.
A time entry cannot overlap with another time entry for the same employee.
A break cannot overlap with another break.
A break must occur within its parent time entry (it can’t start before clock-in or end after clock-out).
The total break duration cannot exceed the time entry duration.
The sum of all break durations within an entry cannot exceed 24 hours (hard cap).
Restricting to add a future dated time entry.
If any rule is violated, the entry is blocked and an error message explains what to fix.
Adding time entry by Clock In/Out
Date & Time: Enter the date, Clock In, and Clock Out for the time entry.
Job: Select the Job/Assignment the employee worked under.
Shift (optional): Choose the Shift if one is assigned for that date.
Breaks (optional): Click Add Break to manually record any Break In/Out times.

Apply Break Rule (optional): Check this to let UZIO evaluate the entry against the assigned Break Rule—eligible breaks are inserted automatically; missed/late/short breaks are flagged and any configured premiums are applied.
Notes (recommended): Add a brief reason/context for audit and approvals
Adding time entry by Duration
Date & Duration: Enter the date and the total duration (hours/minutes) for the time entry.
Job: Select the Job/Assignment the employee worked under.
Shift (optional): Choose the Shift if one is assigned for that date.
Breaks (optional): Click Add Break to record any breaks taken so the entry reflects accurate worked time.
Notes (recommended): Add a brief reason/context for audit and approvals.
Editing a Time Entry
To make the modifications in the time entry, you can edit it. To edit a time entry, Open the Timesheet page
Choose Edit on the relevant row, and update the fields in the pop-up.

You can adjust Clock In/Out times, Shift, Job/Assignment, Duration, and Break In/Out times; you may also add or delete breaks and update any break premiums. Standard validations apply (no overlaps, breaks must sit within the entry, etc.), and an error will explain any issue that needs correction.
You cannot adjust the time entry date as well as its type (Clock In/Out vs Duration)

When you save changes, UZIO recalculates break premiums based on the breaks actually taken and any breaks that are now considered missed/short under the assigned Break Rule. The system then compares the newly calculated premium with the previously applied premium on the entry and lets you choose which one to keep—Use Newly Calculated or Keep Existing. This gives employer users flexibility to override premiums when justified (e.g., manager-approved exceptions) or to apply policy as configured when recalculation is correct.
All updates—including premium selections—are recorded in the audit trail with who made the change, when, and any required notes, ensuring transparency for reviews and payroll.
An employee cannot edit a time entry once the manager has approved the time hours and a manager cannot edit the time entry once the hours are synced to payroll.
Once an entry is edited, the payroll hours are automatically updated as per the new records.
Deleting a Time Entry

To delete a time entry, open the Timesheet page, click Delete on the relevant row, and confirm in the pop-up. Deletion is permanent—the entry cannot be restored and will no longer appear on the timesheet or related views. Any attached breaks and premiums are removed with the entry.
Manager approval for Employee Modifications

Enable manager sign-off on employee changes by turning on “Require manager approval whenever an employee manually adds or edits a time entry” in Time Tracking Settings → Time Clocks. When enabled, any employee add/edit is routed to the manager for approval before it is applied to the timesheet.

Managers can view the old and new values of the edited time entries and can approve. If the managers do not want to approve, then they can edit the time entry and can revert the changes manually. Managers can perform the same action on the web as well as on mobile applications.
Also, till the time manager’s approval is pending the time hours cannot be approved.
Time Attestation

Time attestation asks employees to confirm the accuracy of their hours—and, when applicable, whether they had a fair opportunity to take required breaks. It strengthens compliance, reduces disputes, and creates a clear record for audits and payroll.
Configuration
Enable Time Entry Attestation: Time Tracking Settings → Time Clocks -> Require Employee Attestation for time entries?
Enable Break Attestation: In the relevant Break Rule → Resolving Missed Breaks -> Break Attestation Required?

Both types of attestation appear on the same screen in UZIO. Attestation prompts are shown at clock-out on the web, mobile, or kiosk—based on how you configure the policy. Employees review their day and respond before the entry is saved.
Time Attestation by Employees
Employee taps Clock Out.
UZIO checks for required attestation and shows on the same screen-
If a missed break exception exists and break attestation is enabled at break setup level, the employee answers the missed-break question(s) and may add a note.
If time attestation is enabled, the employee confirms day-level accuracy.
It includes Clock In Time, Clock Out Time, All breaks taken, Shift (If selected) and Assigned job.
The entry is saved, and the attestation is written to the audit trail.

UZIO logs the full context in the audit trail: who attested, timestamp, source (web, mobile, kiosk), and the related entry identifiers. For break attestation, UZIO also records whether the break was added, missed due to work, or missed by choice, and applies any configured premiums or flags.
Missed Time Attestation Notification
The employer can configure if they want to send the notifications to employees for their not attested time entries. They can configure this from the Time Tracking Settings -> Time Clocks ->
The employer can choose the channel of notification by selecting Email/SMS/Push notification. The UZIO sends two notifications
Daily Notification

Each day, UZIO checks whether any employees have not attested time entry for the previous day. If any are found, the system automatically sends a reminder notification (via the channels you’ve enabled—Email/SMS/Push).

Our system records indicate that you have 2 "Not Attested" time entries for 09/11/ 2025. You are advised to attest the time entries to be compliant. Click here to login.
Thank you

At the end of each pay period, UZIO checks whether any employees have not attested time entry for the previous pay period. If any are found, the system automatically sends a reminder notification (via the channels you’ve enabled—Email/SMS/Push).
